BridgeIt

Contact List Demo

Web...meet Native

A 5 minute introduction to getting started with native mobile integration with BridgeIt.

What is BridgeIt?

  • Easily add native mobile features to your web apps
  • Simple JavaScript API
  • Open Source...fork us on GitHub!
  • Support for Android, iOS, and Windows Phone 8

What are we going to do?

  • Create a simple mobile web page
  • Add BridgeIt support
  • Access the native mobile contact list
  • Show the contacts on our web page

Show the user a button

Access the contacts app

Display the contact info in our app

Step 1

Create a mobile page

Add jQuery Mobile

<head>
	<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
	<link rel="stylesheet" 
		href="http://code.jquery.com/mobile/1.3.2/jquery.mobile-1.3.2.min.css"/>
	<script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.9.1.min.js"></script>
	<script src="http://code.jquery.com/mobile/1.3.2/jquery.mobile-1.3.2.min.js"></script>
 </head>
 <body>
 ...

...or use whatever mobile framework you like... it's all good.

Set up a simple mobile page

<div data-role="page">
    <div data-role="header">
        <h1>My Contacts</h1>
    </div><!-- /header -->
    <div data-role="content">
    	<a type="button">Fetch a Contact</a>
    	<p>
            <ul data-role="listview" 
                data-filter="true" 
                data-filter-placeholder="Contact List..." 
                data-inset="true">
            </ul>
        </p>
    </div><!-- /content -->
</div><!-- /page -->
 ...

...or use whatever mobile framework you like... it's all good.

We should have something like this now...

Step 2

Add BridgeIt Mobile Support

 

Add bridgeit.js

<head>
	<script type="application/javascript" 
		src="http://api.bridgeit.mobi/bridgeit/bridgeit.js"></script>
 </head>
 <body>
 ...

Add the BridgeIt fetchContact call

<a type="button" onclick="bridgeit.fetchContact();">
    Fetch a Contact
</a>
 ...

Add an id for the fetchContact call

<a type="button" onclick="bridgeit.fetchContact('myContacts');">
    Fetch a Contact
</a>
 ...

Add a callback for the fetchContact call

<a type="button" onclick="bridgeit.fetchContact('myContacts', 'onAfterFetchContacts');">
    Fetch a Contact
</a>

Why is the function passed as a String??

BridgeIt needs to store the name of the function to call it later..

Add the callback function

<script type="text/javascript">
function onAfterFetchContact(event){
	
}
</script>

Now we should be launched into our Contacts apps when we click the button..

Step 3

Display the Contact Info in your app

 

We can work with the selected contact info in our callback

<script type="text/javascript">
function onAfterFetchContact(event){
	var text = unescape(event.value);
    var record = bridgeit.url2Object(text);
    var elem = document.getElementById("contacts");
    var item = document.createElement('li');
    var recordHTML = '';
    for (var key in record)  {
        recordHTML += "<span><strong>" + key + ": </strong>" + record[key] + "</span><br/>";  
    }
    item.innerHTML = recordHTML;
    elem.insertBefore(item, elem.firstChild);
    $( "#contacts" ).listview( "refresh" );
}
</script>

We should have something like this now...

BridgeIt

Now how long did that take?

I wonder how long an actual mobile app would take?
